text:
Eighteenth Ave., west side, between 85th and 84th Streets. At the left, is seen the West End line of the B.M.T., on New Utrecht Ave. At the right, is the dunther Railway line and private right of way. It was built in 1863, by C. Godfrey Gunther Fur merchant and Miyor of the City of New York. It ran from 25th Street and Fifth Ave., (Brooklyn), to Coney Tsland. It was also known as the Brooklyn Bath and Coney Island R.R. It is now operated by a trolley Company. At the left, in the triangle, once stood the foundry of Michael Feigel, builder of street and railroad
Cars.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(1)
84th Street, north side, between Eighteenth and Nineteenth Aves.
A view of the 'New Utrecht Dutch Reformed Church'.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(2) Same, showing an easterly view in the summer.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster.
(3) Same, showing Liberty Pole, opposite Eighteenth Ave., in the foreground.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(1)
84th Street, north side, between Eighteenth and Nineteenth Aves. This is the New Utrecht Dutch Reformed Church. In the background, is the Van Pelt Manor, built in 1664, acquired by the City of New York, in
1925.
April 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(2)
Same, showing a broader view to the east.
April 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(3)
Same, showing a southeast exposure.
February 1923.
Eugene LC Armbruster Collection.
(4)
Same, from another angle, The bell in the belfry, was imported
from Holland.
February 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

84th Street, north side, between Eighteenth and Nineteenth Aves. A view of the New Utrecht Dutch Reformed Church. In the background, are homes
facing 81st Street. At left Eighteenth Ave., is visible.
1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

84th Street, north side, between Eighteenth and Nineteenth Aves. A view of the Dutch Reformed Church of New Utrecht, formerly a part of the
Van Pelt Manor.
1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

January 11, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

1841 84th Street, north side, between 19th and 18th Aves. The view shows The Bensonhurst Branch of the Y. M. C. A. The building concerned is a frame house.
January 11, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
